title: Match Senses to Sensors
description_teacher: Students match human senses (eyes, ears, touch) to computer sensors (camera, microphone, touch screen). They learn that computers use sensors like we use our senses.
student_prompt: Match the human sense to what the computer uses!

student_prompt_audio.tts_text: Match the human sense to what the computer uses!

correct.message: Perfect! Computers have sensors like we have senses!
correct.audio_tts: Perfect! Computers have sensors like we have senses!

incorrect.message: Try again! What does the camera do like our eyes?
incorrect.audio_tts: Try again! What does the camera do like our eyes?
incorrect.hint_text: Eyes see, and cameras see too!

notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - human-computer sensing comparison

title: What Can Computers Sense?
description_teacher: Students compare what humans and computers can sense using picture examples. They identify things both can sense (light, sound) and things only one can sense (smell, radio waves).
student_prompt: Can a computer sense this? Can you sense it?

student_prompt_audio.tts_text: Can a computer sense this? Can you sense it?

correct.message: Great! You know what computers can sense!
correct.audio_tts: Great! You know what computers can sense!

incorrect.message: Think about it! Can a computer smell cookies?
incorrect.audio_tts: Think about it! Can a computer smell cookies?
incorrect.hint_text: Computers can see and hear, but not smell or taste!

notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - sensing capabilities comparison

title: Computers Need Sensors to Know Things
description_teacher: Students match sensors to the information they provide (camera shows pictures, microphone hears sounds, thermometer measures temperature). They understand that computers need sensors to gather information from the world.
student_prompt: Match the sensor to what it tells the computer!

student_prompt_audio.tts_text: Match the sensor to what it tells the computer!

correct.message: Perfect! Sensors help computers learn about the world!
correct.audio_tts: Perfect! Sensors help computers learn about the world!

incorrect.message: Try again! What does each sensor do?
incorrect.audio_tts: Try again! What does each sensor do?
incorrect.hint_text: A camera takes pictures for the computer to see.

notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - sensors provide information

title: Draw to Show What You See
description_teacher: Students create simple representations of objects by selecting/drawing basic shapes (how to show a tree? a house? a person?). They learn that we can represent things in different ways.
student_prompt: Pick shapes to show what you see!

student_prompt_audio.tts_text: Pick shapes to show what you see!

correct.message: Great! You made a picture with shapes!
correct.audio_tts: Great! You made a picture with shapes!

incorrect.message: Good try! Can you add more to show it better?
incorrect.audio_tts: Good try! Can you add more to show it better?
incorrect.hint_text: What shape is the trunk of a tree?

notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - basic object representation

title: Picture a Story in Order
description_teacher: Students represent a sequence or story using pictures selected from options. They learn that pictures can represent events and we can show order with sequences.
student_prompt: Pick pictures to show the story in order!

student_prompt_audio.tts_text: Pick pictures to show the story in order!

correct.message: Perfect! Your pictures tell the story in order!
correct.audio_tts: Perfect! Your pictures tell the story in order!

incorrect.message: Almost! Check the order of what happens.
incorrect.audio_tts: Almost! Check the order of what happens.
incorrect.hint_text: What happens first in the morning?

notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - sequential representation

title: Map Your Space
description_teacher: Students create a simple map by placing icons to represent objects in a space (classroom, playground, or route). They learn that maps are representations that show where things are.
student_prompt: Make a map to show where things are!

student_prompt_audio.tts_text: Make a map to show where things are!

correct.message: Excellent map! You showed where everything is!
correct.audio_tts: Excellent map! You showed where everything is!

incorrect.message: Good try! Is everything in the right place?
incorrect.audio_tts: Good try! Is everything in the right place?
incorrect.hint_text: The door should be at the front of the room.

notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - spatial representation

title: Design a Map for Navigation
description: Students create an abstract map to solve a navigation problem (e.g., shortest path from home to school, route through a maze). They choose what details to include (landmarks, distances, obstacles) and what to leave out. They understand that good representations include important information and skip unnecessary details.
notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - problem-solving through representation

title: Choose What Matters in Your Representation
description: Students represent the same information in different ways (a daily routine as pictures, as a flowchart, as a schedule) and choose what details to include for different purposes. They understand that: (1) different representations are useful for different tasks, (2) we must choose what information is important, and (3) some details can be left out without losing meaning.
notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - abstraction and feature selection

title: Compare Representations for Different Tasks
description: Students create multiple representations of the same data (e.g., student heights as a table, bar chart, line graph, or descriptive text) and compare usefulness for different tasks: Which is best for finding the tallest student? Which shows growth over time? Which is easiest to understand quickly? They learn to evaluate tradeoffs between different representations.
notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - representation evaluation

title: Design an Infographic
description: Students design a visual representation (infographic style) for a complex system or dataset. They must: (1) choose what data to highlight, (2) select appropriate visual elements (charts, icons, colors), (3) organize information hierarchically (what's most important?), and (4) make it understandable to their target audience. They understand that effective representations combine clarity, accuracy, and visual appeal.
notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - complex information design

title: Representation Tradeoffs: Detail vs. Simplicity
description: Students analyze and evaluate tradeoffs between different data representations: detailed vs. simple, accurate vs. usable, precise vs. understandable. They examine real examples (e.g., weather forecasts, nutritional labels, maps) and discuss: What information is emphasized? What is hidden or simplified? Who benefits from this representation? They learn that representation choices involve tradeoffs and reflect priorities.
notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - critical evaluation of representations

title: Feature Vectors for AI Classification
description: Students create feature vectors to represent data for an AI classification task. For example, representing animals for classification: [has_fur: 1, number_of_legs: 4, can_fly: 0, habitat: 'land']. They understand that: (1) AI needs data in numerical/categorical format, (2) choosing the right features is crucial for AI performance, (3) some features are more informative than others, and (4) representation affects what the AI can learn. This bridges representation to machine learning.
notes: NEW: Added for AI4K12 alignment - AI-specific data representation
